description: From Middle English bredthe, alteration (due to nouns ending in -th: length, strength, wrength, etc.) of brede ("breadth"; see bread). Equivalent to broad +‎ -th. Cognate with Scots bredth (“breadth”), Saterland Frisian Bratte (“breadth”), West Frisian breedte (“breadth”), Dutch breedte (“breadth”), German Low German Breddte, Breddt (“breadth”), German Breite (“breadth”), Danish bredde (“breadth”), Norwegian Bokmål bredde (“breadth”), Swedish bredd (“breadth”).

entries.meaning: The extent or measure of how broad or wide something is.
examples: The breadth of the corridor is 4.5 metres.

entries.meaning: A piece of fabric of standard width.
Scope or range, especially of knowledge or skill.
(art) A style in painting in which details are strictly subordinated to the harmony of the whole composition.
(graph theory) The length of the longest path between two vertices in a graph.
